Award.AbstractNarration: The proposed project will address the question of how experiments at current and future particle accelerators, in particular the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, can help us understand the Standard Model of Particle Physics, electroweak symmetry breaking and dark matter. Part of the planned project focuses on theoretical models that can simultaneously explain the scale of electroweak symmetry breaking and the nature of dark matter in the form of weakly interacting massive particles. Different models and their potential experimental signatures will be compared, in order to develop model-independent analysis techniques. The proposed research work, while theoretical in nature, will be directly beneficial for the experimental LHC collaborations. The other part of the project focuses on effective field theory applications for heavy quark, collider, and gravitational physics. In particular developing an effective field theory for calculating low-x physics and the use of an effective field theory for gravity to investigate questions of interest to LIGO and LISA. The broader implications of this proposal are that this project examines several fundamental issues including questions of direct phenomenological relevance to present and future generations of particle accelerators. The issues studied will have a direct bearing on the interpretation of results from these facilities. The proposed project is well suited for the participation of students at different levels, allowing them to acquire knowledge and skills in theoretical physics, mathematical methods, computer programming and data analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has contributed to developing a solid theoretical and phenomenological foundation for interpreting results from current particle physics and astrophysics experiments, in particular the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). Among other things, the experiments will help us understand why different elementary particles have different properties, why the universe has more matter than antimatter, and the nature of dark matter. However, the identification of interesting new-physics signals in collider and astrophysics experiments is like searching for a needle in a haystack and requires precise theoretical calculations and simulations to achieve this task.

In practice, to make calculations tractable, one must apply suitable approximations. One very common way of doing this is based on the observation that most particles interact relatively weakly with each other, so it is often sufficient to compute only a limited number of interactions for a given process (this is called "perturbative expansion"). However, even with this simplification, there are complicated integrals, which in general can only be solved numerically on a computer. The work of Freitas has made progress in this direction by studying several numerical calculation methods. This work has led to a more precise prediction for the production of bottom quarks at an older collider called LEP. When comparing with data, this result more tightly constrains the Standard Model of particle physics or any extended models. Freitas released a public computer code for performing these numerical integrals, for use by other researchers.

Another approximation method uses the fact that physics processes happen at different length scales. For example, understanding chemical reactions does not depend on the detailed structure of the atomic nucleus, which is much smaller than the atom. The general formalism for separating such widely different scales is called "effective field theory" (EFT), which approximates the full theory of interest. The research of Leibovich under this grant was focused on using EFTs to make calculations relevant to the current experimental program. 

Leibovich and collaborators looked at summing up large effects using EFTs due to the fact that energetic particles are generally produced with many low-energy hadrons, which are missed by the perturbative expansion. One application is the production of bound states of two charm or bottom quarks, called quarkonium, produced copiously at the LHC and similar colliders.  Leibovich and collaborators discussed a new production mechanism for quarkonium, which may help resolve discrepancies of previous theoretical calculations.  Another application is the production of a Higgs boson with a W or Z boson.  Discovery of the Higgs is one of the major goals of the LHC, making this calculation very important.

Outside of particle physics, an interesting problem is the emission of gravitational waves from two black holes orbiting each other. Gravitational waves may be directly observed in the near future by the detectors LIGO and VIRGO. In order to analyze their data, however, one needs to accurately predict the motion of the black holes as they emit gravitational waves and thus lose energy. Leibovich and a collaborator calculated how the emitted waves push on the black holes. They were the first calculate this using EFT to this precision and will use this approach to carry out the calculation to a higher level of precision than has been done.

Besides discovering the Higgs, the LHC may also find evidence for new particles predicted by theoretical models that try to explain what dark matter is and how all forces may be unified together.
